milestone.n: Combat of the Bodhisattva with Māra

seg.seg: ... the heaven somehow remains ... . The serpents (were like) a cover ...
... amidst ... they frighten like wolves. The prince ...
... the lord (says) to lord Māra: "Look, look here! All the g(ods) of this [world] (are witness) ...
... the (pla)nets. Lightning, mount Sumeru, the Gaṅgā, the ocean, the Bra(hmā world) ...
... inside the prince (light shone) like the world [shines] under the sun [and] the moon. 27. Lord Māra ...
... in order to burn. The whole world together with earth [and] heaven entirely glowed and there was no ...
... (the world?) was (afr)aid of the bolt of Prince Kāma [lit. sexual desire] like of the bolt of Mahīśvara [the earth lord] ...
... the whole world was somehow covered by serpents ...
... with ... [and] serpents. Lord Māra threw [his] arrow called "Delusion" [Skt. mohana-] ...
Gott Māra entließ den Pfeil namens mohana ["Blendwerk, Täuschung"].
The god Māra released the arrow named mohana ["Illusion, deception"].
... he changes himself into the Nāga called ... . Then the prince threw a bolt ...
... [his] arrow called the Brahmaśiras [lit. Brahmā's head] of Arrogance. The elephants ...
... the elephants of ... . 30. Lord Māra threw [his] arrow (called the) ... of Deceit ...
... the bolts (call)ed ... (were thrown) by lord Māra who had changed himself into a mountain. ...
... he [= Bodhisattva] threw the arrow of Renunciation [Skt. tyāga-], [which is] emitting a sweet rain. ...
... he [= Māra] threw the arrow [consisting] of the five sensorial aggregates [Skt. pañcaskandha-] having changed himself into wind. ...
... then [the Bodhisattva] threw the bolt of the True View [Skt. samyagdṛṣṭi-] [which] kill(s all passions). ...

p.note: The text is basically classical TB, but is has many archaic spellings including several instances of word-final -ä. It is likely that it has been copied from an archaic manuscript precisely like PK NS 39. This is proven by the hypercorrect spelling makte for mäkte in a3.
ramt\ (a2) and omp\ (a3) have virāma writing of the akālk-type. This type is also often attested on the leaf , which belongs to the same manuscript.

This description of fierce animals belongs to the stereotype of Māra's army. Even though this host of beasts is supposed to be frightening by itself, the Boddhisattva is actually not afraid. In addition, since this seems to be a prose text, the finite verb wīyäskeṃ should close the sentence, so that the next word cannot be its direct object but should start a new sentence. Note that wolves are mentioned as part of the standard list of beasts belonging to Māra's host.

The first sentence is part of the dialgue between Māra and the Bodhisattva, during which the latter invokes the earth goddess as witness.This testimony of the whole earth including all gods immediately causes all the parts of the world to shake six times.

Since in the traditional account this assault of Māra failed, he has recourse to his daughters whom he sents to seduce the Bodhisattva. In our text it appears that Māra is instead himself represented by god Kāma [= desire], who has five arrows according to Indian tradition. These arrows have different names and correspond to various components of love. One of them is precisely Skt. mohana- 'delusion' occurring here in line b3.
The damaged sign at the end of the line can be ‹wa›, ‹la›, or ‹o›.
The remains of the damaged sign does not allow for the correct form parska, so we have here again an archaic spelling pärska.

The adversaries use two different missile weapons: tsain and āsträ. Pace 246, n. 55, tsain is not exclusively used by the Bodhisattva just like āsträ is not exclusively used by Māra. tsain is a loan from Iranian and has originally a broader meaning 'weapon' while Skt. astra- is a missile weapon, usually 'arrow, bolt'.

The best reading is rntsa; before that we seem to have a ligatura that may end in ‹ya› or include a u-vowel. Therefore it is likely that we have the end of a nominal clause with perlative plural with serpent as first member.

Brahmaśiras is the name of a mythical weapon [lit. Brahmā's head], which is used here as metaphor for excessive arrogance. The clause would correspond to a Sanskrit comparative compound *māna-brahmaśiras- of the type strī-ratna- 'jewel of a woman' = 'jewel-like woman'.
It is impossible to read and restore waike (ñ)e(m).
tärkä(namane) stands for standard tärkanamane, which has the expected longer ana-suffix of a prose form without syncope.
